quoteFirst: Last night the Russians had entrenched themselves in a strong position in front of the enemy, and the Russian General, WIDDICOMB, turned the right wing--a wrong one having been turned by the negligence of a scene-shifter. The enemy were in position
quoteLast: , and a French officer made towards a standard, which he eventually carried. On Saturday afternoon a body of Russian soldiers received their pay from the treasury, which is understood to be amply supplied.
title: Punch - Volume 25 (Jul-Dec 1853)
author: Various

quoteLast: .--Meeting of exiles at which Charles and I are present.
title: The Memoirs of Victor Hugo
author: Hugo, Victor, 1802-1885

quoteLast: . I was ready early, waiting on the piazza for the aid to fate that was to keep me from the punishment of going. No human being had spoken his name that morning. How should I know whether he were still so ill or no.
title: Richard Vandermarck: A Novel
author: Harris, Miriam Coles, 1834-1925

quoteLast: , Bilto, Cummin; 10 o'clock, Sayer, Long. Thursday, 9 o'clock—”
title: The Gods and Mr. Perrin: A Tragi-Comedy
author: Walpole, Hugh, 1884-1941

quoteFirst: Morgan and I wanted to take the night train from Paris to Marseilles, twelve hours’ ride. One train carried a sleeping-car. It left Paris
quoteLast: at night and reached Marseilles at 9 o’clock the next morning. Only passengers with first-class tickets can ride on it.
title: A Journey of a Jayhawker
author: Morgan, W. Y. (William Yoast), 1866-1932; Reid, Albert Turner, 1873-1955 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: “SIR ASHTON LEVER’S Lottery Tickets are now on sale at Leicester House, every day (Sunday excepted) from
quoteLast: ing till six in the evening, at one guinea each; and, as each ticket will admit four persons, either together or separately, to view the Museum, no one will hereafter be admitted but by the Lottery Tickets, excepting those who have already annual tickets.
title: A history of English lotteries
author: Ashton, John, 1834-1911

quoteFirst: "No, they beat the Boers off splendidly. However, they had hard work to do it, for the heliograph flashed a signal at about
quoteLast: in the morning to say that they had so far beaten off the enemy, but were much pressed. We heard the next day that this had indeed been the case. Caesar's Camp had been taken and retaken several times--by our men at the point of the bayonet, by the Boers, by rushing up in overwhelming numbers.
title: With Buller in Natal, Or, a Born Leader
author: Henty, G. A. (George Alfred), 1832-1902

quoteFirst: “Also several other surprising Creatures of different sorts. To be seen from
quoteLast: ing till 9 at night, till they are sold. Also, all manner of curiosities of different sorts, are bought and sold at the above place by John Bennett.”
title: Merrie England in the Olden Time, Vol. 1
author: Daniel, George, 1789-1864; Cruikshank, Robert, 1789-1856 [Illustrator]; Gilks, Thomas [Illustrator]; Leech, John, 1817-1864 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: So I spent the evening in writing letters, looking up my 'Instructions,' and filling up my diary. For this day, interviews with officials accounted for at least five hours. Next morning
quoteLast: Conductor Prigge turned up, looking more perky than ever. He had all the airs of a professor, a police officer, and a drill sergeant rolled into one. "Our first business will be to study the map," he said.
title: Meccania, the Super-State
author: Gregory, Owen

quoteFirst: The testimony of Icarus M. Pappas was taken
quoteLast: , on July 29, 1964, at 200 Maryland Avenue NE., Washington, D.C., by Mr. Burt W. Griffin, assistant counsel of the President’s Commission.
title: Warren Commission (15 of 26): Hearings Vol. XV (of 15)
author: United States. Warren Commission
